name: Kepler-120
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-120 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-120 is a star with 0.42999999999999977 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.53 times its radius. It is located 1281.86 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-120 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-120 b

Kepler-120 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.06 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 6.31 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-120.

The mass of Kepler-120 b is 6.05 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-120 b is 2.15 that of Earth. At 6.05 Earth masses, Kepler-120 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-120 c

Kepler-120 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.09 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 12.79 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-120.

The mass of Kepler-120 c is 2.65 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-120 c is 1.53 that of Earth. At 2.65 Earth masses, Kepler-120 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-120, which contains 2 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
